title: 104_hr2512
content: The Act may be cited as the "Crow Creek Sioux Tribe Infrastructure Development Trust Fund Act of 1996". The Congress approved the Pick-Sloan Missouri River basin program in 1944 to promote economic development, provide irrigation, protect from floods, and other purposes. The Fort Randall and Big Bend projects are key components, generating hydropower and impounding water. These projects are located on the western boundary of the Crow Creek Indian Reservation. Public Law 87-735 authorized the acquisition of Indian land on the Crow Creek Indian Reservation for the Fort Randall and Big Bend projects, with provisions for mitigation of their effects. The acquisition of Indian land on the Crow Creek Indian Reservation for the Fort Randall and Big Bend projects includes provisions for essential governmental facilities, a townsite for 50 homes with utilities, and a community center for tribal offices and gatherings. The Crow Creek Indian Reservation lacks fulfillment of obligations under Public Law 87-735 for mitigation of effects from the Fort Randall and Big Bend projects. Despite national economic benefits, the reservation's economy remains underdeveloped. Increased tribal participation in the projects will enhance economic, social, and cultural development for the Crow Creek Sioux Tribe. The Crow Creek Sioux Tribe is entitled to additional benefits from the Pick-Sloan Missouri River basin program. The Crow Creek Sioux Tribe Infrastructure Development Trust Fund, Plan for socioeconomic recovery and cultural preservation, Program administered by Western Area Power Administration, Secretary of the Interior, Tribe of Crow Creek Sioux Tribe of Indians recognized by the United States. The Crow Creek Sioux Tribe Infrastructure Development Trust Fund is established in the Treasury of the United States to receive funding for infrastructure development. The Secretary of the Treasury will deposit 25 percent of receipts from the Program annually until reaching $27,500,000. Investments will be made in interest-bearing obligations of the United States. Interest earned will be transferred to the Tribe. The Secretary of the Treasury transfers interest accrued on deposited amounts into a separate account. Once the Fund reaches a specified amount, funds are available to the Secretary of the Interior for use in accordance with specified guidelines. The Secretary of the Treasury transfers funds to the Secretary of the Interior for payments to the Tribe for specific projects and programs outlined in a plan. Payments cannot be distributed on a per capita basis to any Tribe member. The Secretary of the Treasury may not transfer or withdraw any amount deposited under subsection (b) for the Tribe on a per capita basis. SEC. 5. PLAN FOR SOCIOECONOMIC RECOVERY AND CULTURAL PRESERVATION. The Tribe must prepare a plan within 2 years for the use of payments received under the Act, consulting with relevant authorities. The plan must identify costs, benefits, and provide plans for each component. It includes programs like an educational facility and comprehensive healthcare facility on the Crow Creek Indian Reservation. The plan for the Crow Creek Indian Reservation includes a comprehensive healthcare facility, a water system, and recreational facilities at Lake Sharpe and other locations. The plan for the Crow Creek Indian Reservation includes projects and programs for educational, social welfare, economic development, and cultural preservation as deemed appropriate by the Tribe. SEC. 6. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Funds are authorized to carry out this Act, including administrative expenses of the Crow Creek Sioux Tribe Infrastructure Development Trust Fund. SEC. 7. EFFECT OF PAYMENTS TO TRIBE. SEC. 7. EFFECT OF PAYMENTS TO TRIBE. No payment made to the Tribe under this Act shall impact existing services or programs for the Tribe or its members. Payments will not affect power rates or tribal rights not addressed in the Act.
